newsitem.title: USA: Sen. Grassley sees support for US ethanol subsidy.
newsitem.headline: Sen. Grassley sees support for US ethanol subsidy.

text.p: Sen. Charles Grassley said Wednesday there was bipartisan support to extend the ethanol subsidy after its expiry at the end of 2000.

But he acknowledged that House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Bill Archer, a Texas Republican, who strongly opposes extending the subsidy, was not to be underestimated in his efforts to abolish it.

Grassley, an Iowa Republican, said extending the ethanol subsidy had support in the Senate, among House Democrats and from the White House. "It seems to me that we're in a very, very strong position," he told reporters.
The House tax bill would eliminate the ethanol subsidy after it expired, while the Senate bill would reduce the subsidy from 2001 to 2007.
"I'm hoping that somewhere between the year 2000 and 2007, with my preference being the year 2007, we're in a strong position to get some extension of the ethanol exemption," Grassley said.
"I know this is a very key issue for Archer and I don't underestimate Archer's ability to be tough," he said.
